issue.title: P2P block inv notification bug
issue.body:
Connecting with a whitebinded peer on localshost to P2P, Bitcoin Core selectively sends block invs after `generatetoaddress 10 address` RPC command.

**Expected behavior**

Send block invs for every block generated in the proper order.

**To reproduce**

1. Connect to bitcoind with a whitebinded local peer and listen to the invs. 
2. Generate 10 blocks with RPC in one command: `generatetoaddress 10 address`
3. Only get some invs. On my computer it's 7, on @lontivero's computer it's 2.

**System information**

Ubuntu 18.04, Windows 10, Bitooin Core 0.18.1

events.body:
Below is the log that shows that 10 blocks are created but only 9 inv messages are sent. I've run our test many times and 9 is the maximum number of invs messages that I've received when using `generatetoaddress 10 address`.

However, if we introduce a one second wait in between of each block creation, the 10 invs are sent as expected, this is:
```
generatetoaddress 1 address
sleep 1
generatetoaddress 1 address
sleep 1
generatetoaddress 1 address
sleep 1
...
...
```

Also, the node had time to send the inv message for the latest block because there are 2 minutes between the last inv message and the rpc stop request.   

---------------------

## Log

issue.title: [Bug] Unable to rescan
issue.body:
Somehow my balance got corrupt.
Only the 2 last transactions I made appear.

I tried to cause a rescan by changing to testnet and back to mainnet, but it did not work.

events.body: @lontivero just to add to this log: the problem is that `0ec957f5349e856c1a24f0ca785446bfc65d02f91f3d33084696fae446243974` was never announced via a inv.
It is strange, it never happened to me but the log seems to indeed show that a block was not announced.

This seems to be the case if direct headers announcement / BIP 130 is not used (is there a reason for that?) and if the blocks are generated faster than the propagation mechanism with validationinterface callbacks and SendMessages picks them up - according to the following code comment it is intentional that in this case, only the tip is INV'ed and the rest of the blocks are dropped from `vBlockHashesToAnnounce` and never INV'ed  (I am not sure why):
https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/blob/cd6cb9745e13a62e130b11f78a13bcc1d424b05e/src/net_processing.cpp#L3751-L3754

issue.title: Wasabi mistakenly thinks coin is unspent
issue.body:
### General Description

See https://github.com/zkSNACKs/WalletWasabi/issues/1637#issuecomment-508998457 for context.

In short, with Wasabi v1.1.6, a coin that Wasabi believed it had in its wallet was marked as "spent" when I tried to send it, or register it for CJ. There were no unconfirmed transactions in the history view.

@nopara73 [mentioned](https://github.com/zkSNACKs/WalletWasabi/issues/1637#issuecomment-507026328) that it was known that there could be issues remaining around handling of wallet state cache:

> the wallet state cache issue is not fixed at serialization, but it's corrected at wallet load, so that's a workaround

Restoring the wallet from seed words + passphrase after removing the earlier `.walletwasabi` directory fixed the state of the coins and calculated the expected balance, which does appear to confirm the presence of a logic bug where Wasabi gets confused about the spentness of a coin in some circumstances.

### How To Reproduce?

Unknown currently.

### Operating System

Debian 10

### Wasabi Version

1.1.6, installed from `.deb` downloaded from Github releases page

issue.title: Make Block notifications reliable
issue.body:
Periodically query block notifications through RPC, except if they're triggered manually by P2P.

Closes https://github.com/zkSNACKs/WalletWasabi/pull/2523

It is a workaround for this bug/safety measure: https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/issues/17451

events.body: I think @mzumsande might be right. I never experienced this problem, probably because I use header announcement. You should try to switch to the same by sending a `SendHeaders` upon connection and using new headers announcement instead of the invs.

This behavior is intentional and, in my view, largely correct.  For some history, this code was last restructured in #6494 (merged in #7129) and also discussed in #5982, see in particular [this comment](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/5307#issuecomment-93785348).

I don't think that the goal of the p2p protocol for block announcements is to ensure that every block hash is announced; instead our goal is to ensure that the network synchronizes quickly and reasonably efficiently.  If somehow our queue of block announcements fills to the point that we're falling back to just announcing our tip, it's either because (a) our node is too slow to drain the announcement queue, (b) blocks are arriving way faster than you'd ever expect given our consensus parameters, or (c) we're experiencing a large (>8 block) reorg.

I think (a) is by far the most likely cause that we'd see in practice -- and in the event that we are being slow to process block announcements, it's not important for the network's health to clear through our backlog announcing old blocks.  Scenario (b), which is described in this issue, is unrealistic for mainnet, and (c) should be very rare, so it's something we should handle but not necessarily optimize for, as such a large reorg will already be very disruptive (and it's not clear that having the whole network announce every block hash on every link is better in such a case than just announcing tips and letting nodes decide which peers to sync headers from).

Moreover, as I pointed out in the comment linked above, sending INV messages for lots of intermediate block hashes is inefficient for implementations like Bitcoin Core's, where we send a getheaders message in response to an INV in order to determine whether to download the block (which is necessary for anti-DoS reasons), resulting in n^2 behavior if we were to be announced a quick succession of blocks at once.

That said, if there is a use case of applications listening to (say) a trusted node implementation to be notified of all blocks which is not yet being met using the existing ways (like zmq or -blocknotify or whatever other listening ways we have nowadays), then I think we should improve that.  I would just be skeptical about trying to make the p2p layer serve that need -- and if some use case must use the p2p layer, I would suggest implementing some minimal headers syncing logic to be compatible.

issue.title: Not sending all block messages on regtest after generate a large amount of blocks
issue.body: I am experiencing a bug where on regtest, when one generates a large number of blocks (more than 10) using the `generatetoaddress` CLI command, bitcoind does not send `headers` messages, but instead it sends `inv` messages for the generated blocks. However, the number of `inv` messages does not match the number of the generated blocks.

issue.title: Generating many blocks on regtest bitcoind node peered with neutrino corrupts chaindb
issue.body:
If you peer your bitcoind node with bitcoin-s and then run `bitcoin-cli generatetoaddress 100 $(bitcoin-cli getnewaddress)` you will end up with a corrupted chain state, I believe we are receiving blocks out of order. 

If you generate blocks 1 by 1 with `bitcoin-cli generatetoaddress 1 $(bitcoin-cli getnewaddress)` you will stay in sync with the bitcoind node.

Also if you turn off your neutrino node, and then do `bitcoin-cli generatetoaddress 100 $(bitcoin-cli getnewaddress)` and then restart your node, you will be able to sync fine. 

So the basic issue here is when we are peered with `bitcoind` in regtest and are generating a large amount of blocks. We must have an async bug in the node/chain processing logic. 

I do not have a stack trace at the moment. 

This should be easy to replicate in a unit test, specifically by modifying this unit test: 

https://github.com/bitcoin-s/bitcoin-s/blob/master/node-test/src/test/scala/org/bitcoins/node/NeutrinoNodeTest.scala#L85

The difference between this test case and the one linked above is that the test case above generates the blocks BEFORE starting the neutrino node, this bug occurs while the neutrino node is peered with bitcoind, and then bitcoind generates a burst of blocks. 

This was originally reported by @nkohen
